comments.comment: People don't really expect someone else's opinion on how they should live their lives, do they? "Royal, Red Carpet..." whatever... people don't have to live according to how the British would define things. Also, any particular type of a dress doesn't belong to just J-Lo, Grande or whoever that someone is fan of. No one lives beneath the so called British queen or Hollywood celebrities. If we look into the real history, queens have been the most glorious whores themselves who used female things for their advantage. Just because you chose to live under the British queen and imagine yourself to be a Victorian, you should not judge others based on that. The real shame that we have to deal with is not just a bunch of rich people or drunk women or a party that used the useless word "royal". The real shame and disgrace is that Sri Lanka being a country that runs it's economy by sending poor women to the middleast for slavery in many forms. I think the patriots must start doing something about that rather than being judgemental in the web over a bunch of people just having fun in their own ways. I live in the UK too doing my job and paying lots of taxes to the "her majesty's revenue and customs". Also I see how many of the noble breed just run their lives on the dole, not being crippled or anything but just being lazy. (not so a good reason to feel noble or proud about any nation, is it?). So, I don't think that we have any reason to feel so ashamed of a Sri Lankan person who spent a significant amount of money on his birthday party or those women who chose to get drunk and lived the moment as they want.

comments.comment: What's the big deal here..? This is not personally my cup of tea or how I enjoy life but that doesn't give me the right to judge. The lady in this vedio brags about the fact that she is married to a westerner & that she has lived abroad for so many years, so what!! It's a private party & they have not used any public funds for this birthday bash. I blame the media for portraying this in this way and judgemental people like the lady in this vedio for acting with an "I am better than you attitude". There are parties like this in every part of the world. It's a free world, and as long as no one harms anyone it shouldn't be anyone's damm business. With my experience it's people who keep saying things like "I am not this", "I behave that way" are the worst culprits behind close doors. There are psychological theories on this. By repeatingly denying & judging certain behavior, you are denying your root thoughts. For an example, someone who steals have a tendency to repeatedly say things like "I never steal", "How shameful is it to steal, I can't even dream of doing such things" etc. I am not saying all are like that, but what you are saying is your words, we don't know you enough to decide what your character is. There are bigger social issues in Sri Lanka, I suggest you put your energy & focus on them rather than these petty things..
